title.narrative: Output 1.3 - Implementation of system of monitoring of the progress made to ensure compliance of the national legislations, policies and practices with the ECOWAS Policy Framework on SSRG.
Numbers of monitoring reports produced.

Output 1.2 - Support to a process of assessment, revision, harmonization of the regional/national security and defence related legal framework with a specific attention to the regional police and judiciary capacities to collaborate on criminal matters.
Level of progress in the revision, dissemination and application of security-related policies and legislative framework in Niger, Burkina Faso and Mali.

comment.narrative: 1. A compilation and a preliminary assessment of the security related legal framework has been done in Niger and Mali. 2. Law enforcement institutions and academies have not access to the security related legal framework.

title.narrative: Outcome 2 - Increase confidence and trust by the population of the Liptako Gourma Region in the governmental security institutions.

1. Level of trust and confidence in the security sector actors reported by the population (gender/age) in the Liptako Gourma Region; 2. Perception of a stronger cohesion, respect and confidence between the population and the ISFs.

comment.narrative: 1. Annual Report 2018, DDG Sahel: 80% of communities report an improvement in trust with the Security Services; Monthly Analysis Report of Protection Monitoring Data, December 2018, Tillabéri, Niger: 42 protection incidents including 0% from DSF. Monthly Protection Monitoring Data Analysis Report, December 2019, Tillabéri, Niger: 1% of the 30 protection incidents are attributed to the SDS

title.narrative: Output 3.2 - Strengthening local/regional security mechanism and law enforcement institutions operating in the Liptako Gourma Region.

Institutional framework (laws, policies, procedures and mechanisms) for dealing with gender-based violence
Attitudes and professional practices of security and justice actors towards gender-based violence.

comment.narrative:
Institutional framework (laws, policies, procedures and mechanisms) for dealing with gender-based violence to be revised and/or developed.
Training need on attitude and professional practices.

title.narrative: Output 1.1 - Sensitization and communication to key national stakeholders in Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso on the importance and value of democratic control and oversight of the security sector.
In each of the three countries, level of adhesion by key informers and leaders to basic SSRG concepts (Targeted surveys).

comment.narrative: Low level af knowledge and appropriation by key informers and leaders to basic SSRG concepts (baseline provided by activity 1.1.1) in 2020.

title.narrative: Output 3.1 - Strengthening technical and operating capacities of institutions responsible for providing oversight of defense and security sector resource management processes
Oversight institutions are in capacity to produce reports on resource management of defense and security institutions operating in the Liptako Gourma region.

comment.narrative: Low technical and operating capacities of institutions responsible for providing oversight of defense and security sector resource management processes

title.narrative: Output 2.3 - Strengthening of external oversight institutions through media and civil society engagement, especially in the Liptako Gourma region.

Level and quality of CSO initiatives to proactively channel citizen concerns on security and defense issues at the national and local levels and produce information on the defense and security sector.

comment.narrative: Mali: The development of the SSR national strategy and the subsequent action plan did not significantly involve CSOs or relied on public participation. Among the sixty members of the CNRSS and the fifty members of the CRSS, CSOs are not represented in any of the organs. CSOs are invited from time to time to participate in workshops organized by the CRSS. Niger: Studio Kalangou, our local partner, in partnership with DCAF, produced and disseminated programs on security subjects. Burkina Faso: public oversight is exercised by several civil society organizations (CSOs), as well as by certain media and trade unions that perform multiple functions, but their power and knowledge has to be increased. Liptako Gourma Region: Community radio, traditional communicators, and other media, communication and information present at the local level begin training related to conflict awareness.

title.narrative: Output 2.1 - Strengthening exchanges and communications initiatives on security related issues between state security institutions, government representatives and citizens of the Liptako Gourma region.

Number of communications and exchanges initiatives organized by Governmental authorities and security institutions on security related issues (Including on the abuses committed by the SDS and on the existing complaint mechanisms) in Liptako Gourma, gathering citizens, local government representatives and law enforcement institutions of the Liptako Gourma region.
Outcome 1 - Contribution to the creation of a national and regional environment conducive for/supportive of enhanced oversight and monitoring of the security sector.
Level of progress made by Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger to comply with the ECOWAS Policy Framework for SSRG

comment.narrative:
Provided by activity 1.3 (2019/2020)
In Burkina Faso, in 2017, a 5-year military programming law was adopted.

title.narrative: Outcome 3 - Improved effectiveness and professionalism of the security institutions involved in the Liptako Gourma Region

comment.narrative: Provided by activity 3.2.1 1. In Burkina Faso, the feeling of insecurity in 2017 according to the CGD report is mainly linked to crime through the following offences: theft of animals or cattle (27%), burglaries (22%), theft in the fields (14%), swindling (11%), and armed attacks and assaults (5% 2. In Burkina Faso, 53% of respondents believe that the security services are accessible, 55% believe that they are fast and 73% believe that the security services are efficient according to the survey report conducted in 2017 by the CGD. 3. In Burkina Faso, according to Transparency International-Afrobarometer 2019, the overall corruption rate has evolved from 11% in 2015 to 16% in 2019. For the security sector, in 2019, 29% believe that the police force is corrupt compared to 28% in 2015. As for judges and magistrates, 34% believe that they are corrupt compared to 31% in 2015 and 2019 respectively.

title.narrative: Output 3.3 - Improved security sector response to GBV in the Liptako Gourma region.
Number of security actors trained and who report on increased understanding and readiness to respond to GBV, disaggregated by sex, rank, position, institution and community.

comment.narrative: Security sector structures dealing with cases of GBV: Burkina Faso : Care service and toll-free helpline for GBV victims, staffed with police officers who provide victim support, under the supervision of the Ministry for the Advancement of Women and Gender Equality. Establishment of a police force to detect human trafficking in border areas. Little is known about how operational these services are. Mali : Police - A hotline to tackle GBV was set up in Dec 2013 – the “green line” is meant to be accessible to the whole population. There is a « Brigade de protection des mœurs et de l’enfance » within the direction of the judicial police. There is a judicial investigation brigade as well. Civil protection – no specific training to handle GBV cases Gendarmerie – GBV poles have been established in the regions but lack specific GBV training Niger : majority of survivors do not report GBV because of fear for their security, of stigma, or because perpetrators are family or community members.

title.narrative: Output 2.2 - Parliaments capacities for an effective oversight of the security sector involving defense and security committees is developped
# of questions at the Parliaments of Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso related to the defense and security sector and to the security situation in the Liptako Gourma region
